ygData.subject: Re: Quantitative vs. Qualitative Results
ygData.msgSnippet: Hey Jeff, This is cool work and I think it s a good step toward addressing a fundamentally interesting question: How can we seed an evolving 3D object

Subject: Re: Quantitative vs. Qualitative Results
X-Yahoo-Group-Post: member; u=550414109; y=V_tQUmIR9w74I5vgEPZ1jZ4XsQcbGwCmK1nLaGBLH6wp86tSB-OQZ3l-QP08T2tJ-zw4Ny0HAM0jI8s

Hey Jeff,

This is cool work and I think it's a good step toward addressing=
 a fundamentally interesting question: How can we seed an evolving 3D objec=
t generator with a predetermined object? It's also a great example of what =
I was talking about in my previous comment in response to Ken. First, I'll =
answer your question.

> I won't take any criticism of our paper personally=
. I just think that sometimes arguments are more informative when there is =
a specific example to be discussed, instead of remaining entirely abstract.=
 I also think this paper is a nice example of a technique that can't be qua=
ntified in an informative way, yet remains an interesting contribution. If =
you were our reviewer, would you insist upon a quantitative comparison for =
this paper? How would you recommend such a test be made? Do you agree that =
we should encourage reviewers to reject such papers, or that we should work=
 to encourage reviewers to consider such papers?

I agree that it's hard to=
 quantify the results in this paper because the result is "yup, it worked i=
n my system." At this point, the best you could've done was (as you mention=
ed) compared it to how closely targeted evolution gets to the desired targe=
t. Since you have a measure of how "close" the phenotype is to the target p=
henotype (distanceFromSurface), you can quantify the distance from the desi=
red target that each method achieves. Of course, each method would need to =
be run in replicate at least 30 times to get a reasonable mean and 95% conf=
idence interval.


Some more comments about the paper:

Here's what I got f=
rom the paper: You wanted to create a method to seed a 3D object generator =
with a predetermined 3D object. You devised a method to enable this feature=
 based on CPPNs. You showed that it works pretty well and matches the desir=
ed object on EndlessForms.

Notice how each sentence narrows the relevant a=
udience down more and more. The question went from "How do I seed a 3D obje=
ct generator with a predetermined object?" to "How do I seed a 3D object ge=
nerator based on CPPNs with a predetermined object?" to "How do I seed my 3=
D object generator based on CPPNs, EndlessForms, with a predetermined objec=
t?"

Let's say I had my own 3D object generating website, UnlimitedForms, b=
ut it was based on regular ANNs. What could I take from this paper? Or what=
 if I was only interested in 2D pictures, but still wanted to seed them sim=
ilarly? Or what if I have no interest in evolving 2D/3D objects at all, but=
 want to know clever methods for seeding a GA with a predetermined phenotyp=
e? These are all important points to consider when presenting a new method,=
 especially because everyone has their own pet method that they like to use=
.

If you did the work discussed in Section 4B for this paper, you would ha=
ve a much easier time quantifying the results. You also would've gotten at =
a much more broadly interesting question about evolvability while simultane=
ously presenting your new technique.

Also, given that this is a methods pa=
per, I'm surprised the methods section is so short. The new technique that =
you introduced in this paper (Section 2C) only received about 2/3 page of t=
ext, and no figures dedicated to it. From my first two reads through that s=
ection, I still don't completely understand how the method works. I would s=
ay that that would be the critical section of the paper for readers to unde=
rstand if they were to use your technique, worthy of at least one figure an=
d more detailed explanation.

Cheers,
Randy


--- In neat@yahoogroups.com, =
"Jeff" <jclune@...> wrote:
>
> Hello all,
> 
> Our recent conversation in t=
his "Quantitative vs. Qualitative Results" thread was started in part becau=
se a paper I am on was rejected from GECCO for not having any quantitative =
results. That paper was recently accepted at CEC. I'd be interested to hear=
 your thoughts on this paper in light of our conversation now that you can =
see the specific paper that was rejected. 
> 
> I'd be especially intereste=
d to hear from those of you who argued that non-quantitative papers should =
be rejected (or, at least, should have a much higher threshold to gain acce=
ptance). Obviously I think this paper is interesting and will benefit the s=
cientific community, partly because it suggests new ideas (though it can't =
quantify all of them yet). Do you think our field is better off barring suc=
h papers because they can't quantitatively "prove" they are better than som=
e alternate algorithm in some way? Of course I'm not advocating that all pa=
pers should lack quantitative results; just that we should not rule out suc=
h papers if they don't have statistical comparisons. I do want to stress th=
at I always include--and as a reviewer, insist upon--a statistical test wit=
h a p-value *if* a quantitative claim is made, but that policy is not incon=
sistent with the view that many interesting, subjective, qualitative observ=
ations are scientifically worthwhile too. 
> 
> I won't take any criticism =
of our paper personally. I just think that sometimes arguments are more inf=
ormative when there is a specific example to be discussed, instead of remai=
ning entirely abstract. I also think this paper is a nice example of a tech=
nique that can't be quantified in an informative way, yet remains an intere=
sting contribution. If you were our reviewer, would you insist upon a quant=
itative comparison for this paper? How would you recommend such a test be m=
ade? Do you agree that we should encourage reviewers to reject such papers,=
 or that we should work to encourage reviewers to consider such papers?
> 
=
> Here is the cite and PDF: 
> 
> Clune J, Chen A, Lipson H (2013) Upload A=
ny Object and Evolve it: Injecting Complex Geometric Patterns into CPPNs fo=
r Further Evolution. Proceedings of the IEEE Congress on Evolutionary Compu=
tation.
> 
> http://jeffclune.com/publications/2013-Clune-SeededCPPN-CEC.pd=
f
> 
> I look forward to hearing your thoughts. 
> 
> Best regards,
> Jeff =
Clune
> 
> Assistant Professor
> Computer Science
> University of Wyoming

 jeffclune@...
